hints_html:
Consider the values of both \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{a}{x}\) and \(\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{a}{x}\), where a > 0.

It may be helpful to note that \(\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} f(h)\) and that \(\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow \infty} f(h)\).
hints_latex:
Consider the values of both $\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{a}{x}$ and
$\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{a}{x}$, where \emph{a} \textgreater{} 0.

It may be helpful to note that
$\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} f(h)$ and
that $\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow \infty} f(h)$.
hints_raw:
Consider the values of both <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{a}{x}</math> and <math>\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{a}{x}</math>, where ''a'' > 0.
It may be helpful to note that <math>\lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow 0} f(h)</math> and that <math>\lim_{x \rightarrow 0} f(1/x) = \lim_{h \rightarrow \infty} f(h)</math>.
question: B 08
sols_html:
(i)

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{1/x} = \lim_{h \to \infty} e^{h} = {\color{blue}\infty}\end{aligned}\]

(ii)

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} e^{1/x} = \lim_{h \to 0} e^{h} = e^0 = {\color{blue}1}\end{aligned}\]

(iii)

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}} = \lim_{h \to \infty} \frac{1}{\frac{a}{h} + e^{h}} = {\color{blue}0}\end{aligned}\]

(iv)

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}} = \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{1}{\frac{a}{h} + e^{h}} = {\color{blue}0}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
(i)
: <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{1/x} = \lim_{h \to \infty} e^{h} = {\color{blue} \infty}</math>
(ii)
: <math>\lim_{x \to \infty} e^{1/x} = \lim_{h \to 0} e^{h} = e^0 = {\color{blue} 1}</math>
(iii)
: <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}} = \lim_{h \to \infty} \frac{1}{\frac{a}{h} + e^{h}} = {\color{blue} 0}</math>
(iv)
: <math>\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}} = \lim_{h \to 0^+} \frac{1}{\frac{a}{h} + e^{h}} = {\color{blue} 0}</math>
statement_html:
The velocity of a crawling cell has been modelled as

\(v(x) = \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}}\)

where \(x > 0\) is the number of actin filaments driving the motion and \(a > 0\) is a constant. Determine the following:

(i) \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{1/x}\)

(ii) \(\lim_{x \to \infty} e^{1/x}\)

(iii) \(\lim_{x \to 0^+} v(x)\)

(iv) \(\lim_{x \to \infty} v(x)\)
statement_latex:
The velocity of a crawling cell has been modelled as

$v(x) = \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}}$

where $x > 0$ is the number of actin filaments driving the motion and
$a > 0$ is a constant. Determine the following:

(i) $\lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{1/x}$

(ii) $\lim_{x \to \infty} e^{1/x}$

(iii) $\lim_{x \to 0^+} v(x)$

(iv) $\lim_{x \to \infty} v(x)$
statement_raw:
The velocity of a crawling cell has been modelled as

<math>v(x) = \frac{1}{ax + e^{1/x}}</math>

where <math> x > 0 </math> is the number of actin filaments driving the motion and <math>a > 0</math> is a constant.  Determine the following: 

(i) <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} e^{1/x}</math>

(ii) <math>\lim_{x \to \infty} e^{1/x} </math>

(iii) <math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} v(x)</math>

(iv) <math>\lim_{x \to \infty} v(x) </math>
